title-group.article-title: Anthocyanin 5,3 -aromatic acyltransferase from Gentiana triflora, a structural insight into biosynthesis of a blue anthocyanin

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
Anthocyanin 5,3 ′ -aromatic acyltransferase from
Gentiana triflora
, a structural insight into biosynthesis of a blue anthocyanin

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: ARTICLE INFO

sec.title: Keywords:
sec.p: Structure analysis
Anthocyanin
Delphinidin
Caffeoyl-CoA
Acyltransferase
ABSTRACT

The acylation of anthocyanins contributes to their structural diversity. Aromatic acylation is responsible for the blue color of anthocyanins and certain flowers. Aromatic acyltransferase from
Gentiana triflora Pall. (Gentianaceae)
(Gt5,3 ′ AT ) catalyzes the acylation of glucosyl moieties at the 5 and 3 ′ positions of anthocyanins. Anthocyanin acyltransferase transfers an acyl group to a single position, such that Gt5,3 ′ AT possesses a unique enzymatic activity. Structural investigation of this aromatic acyl group transfer is fundamental to understand the molecular mechanism of the acylation of double positions. In this study, structural analyses of Gt5,3 ′ AT were conducted to identify the underlying mechanism. The crystal structure indicated that Gt5,3 ′ AT shares structural similarities with other BAHD family enzymes, consisting of N and C terminal lobes. Structural comparison revealed that acyl group preference (aromatic or aliphatic) for the enzymes was determined by four amino acid positions, which are well conserved in aromatic and aliphatic CoA-binding acyltransferases. Although a complex structure with anthocyanins was not obtained, the binding of delphinidin 3,5,3 ′ -triglucoside to Gt5,3 ′ AT was investigated by evaluating the molecular dynamics. The simulation indicated that acyl transfer by Gt5,3 ′ AT preferentially occurs at the 5-position rather than at the 3 ′ -position, with interacting amino acids that are mainly located in the C-terminal lobe. Subsequent assays of chimeric enzymes (exchange of the N-terminal lobe and the C-terminal lobe between Gt5,3 ′ AT and lisianthus anthocyanin 5 AT ) demonstrated that acyl transfer selectivity may be caused by the C-terminal lobe.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: In this study, we determined the crystal structures of Gt5,3 ′ AT alone and in a complex with caffeoyl-CoA using molecular replacement at 3.1 and 2.5 Å resolutions, respectively, to identify the molecular basis of substrate specificity. The crystal structures of Gt5,3 ′ AT revealed differences in substrate recognition for an aromatic acyl-CoA donor compared to other flavonoid BAHD AT family enzymes. Additionally, the substrate specificity of Gt5,3 ′ AT is discussed based on the docking model calculations. The specificity of Eg5 AT was successfully modified to harbor 5,3 ′ AT activity based on the crystal structure and docking model.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: 2.1. Structure of gentian acyltransferase

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
The crystal structures of Gt5,3 ′ AT were determined for the apo and complex forms of the His174Ala mutant with caffeoyl-CoA ( Fig. 2 ). In the apo form, the electron density of the region 302–308 was poor and the structural model was not built. The structure is composed of 14 α- helices and 16 β- strands, including several short helices, such as the 310 helix. Although the mutant/truncated Gt5,3 ′ AT was soaked with caffeoyl-CoA and delphinidin 3,5-diglucoside, in the crystal structure, the electron density of delphinidin 3,5-diglucoside could not be found, and caffeoyl-CoA binding was demonstrated by the electron density around the binding pocket ( Fig. 2 ). The adenosine moiety exhibited poor electron density. This is similar to the structural analysis conducted on
Nicotiana tabacum
L . ( Solanaceae ) malonyltransferase (NtMAT1) (
). The two structures (apo and complex forms) were very similar, with an RMSD of 0.47 Å , suggesting that caffeoyl-CoA fit simply to the binding pocket and did not induce significant conformational changes.

sec.title: Orphanage
Orphanage
sec.p:
As a member of the BAHD ATs, Gt5,3 ′ AT possesses two conserved motifs (
): HxxxD and DFGWG . The HxxxD motif is conserved as 174 His-Ser-Ile-Ala-Asp
178 in
Gt5,3 ′ AT .

sec.title: 2.2. Caffeoyl-CoA binding site
sec.p:
Among the three flavonoid BAHD AT enzymes with known structures (Gt5,3 ′ AT , Dm3MAT3, and NtMAT1), Dm3MAT3 and NtMAT1 catalyze the transfer of a malonyl group to flavonoid ligands, while Gt5,3 ′ AT catalyzes the transfer of a caffeoyl/coumaroyl group to the ligand. Acylgroup recognition can occur at the narrow end of the acyl-CoA binding pocket. In the Gt5,3 ′ AT structure, the caffeoyl group is sandwiched between Met43 and Phe182, stabilized by three hydrogen bonds, one between the carbonyl oxygen of the caffeoyl group and Gly401(N) and Thr400(Oγ1), and one between the hydroxyl group at position 3 and Ser45(Oγ) ( Fig. 3A ). The third hydrogen bond is only possible for the caffeoyl group and can contribute to acyl-CoA binding. In our previous study, Gt5,3 ′ AT showed a higher affinity for the caffeoyl group than the coumaroyl group as an acyl-CoA donor (
). As mentioned above, the Gt5,3 ′ AT structure did not show significant conformational changes upon caffeoyl-CoA binding. However, caffeoyl group binding induced a local change in the amino acid structural environment. The Met43 residue in the apo form was directed toward the empty pocket space. In the complex form, the rotamer of methionine changed and created space for caffeoyl group binding ( Fig. 3B ). In addition, the main chain of the loop between α1 and β3 was shifted to extend the pocket: a shift of 0.57 Å at the Cα position of Met43.
a These amino acids form hydrogen bonds with the malonyl/caffeoyl group.

Aromatic acyl-CoA ATs possess Ser/Gln and Phe/Ile/Gly at positions 45 and 182, respectively (Supplementary Figure S1 ). These aromatic acyl-CoA ATs avoid bulky amino acids at critical positions, especially at positions 179 and 401, and maintain sufficient space to adapt to an aromatic acyl-CoA donor. The comparison among the other BAHD ATs with known structures (mentioned above) also supports these observations. Vinorine synthase from
Rauvolfia serpentine
( L .) Benth. Ex Kurz ( Apocynaceae ) is another BAHD superfamily enzyme that is involved in the biosynthesis of the ajmalan-type alkaloid vinorine from the alkaloid 16-epi-vellosimine (
). Structural comparison revealed that this enzyme possesses a valine (Val165) at position 179 in Gt5,3 ′ AT that accepts non-aromatic acyl-CoA ( Fig. 4 ). The important amino acid locations for acyl-CoA specificity are summarized in Fig. 5.

sec.title: 2.3. Internal environment of anthocyanin binding pocket and acylation preference
sec.p:
The structure of Gt5,3 ′ AT is composed of two lobes, the N-lobe and the C-lobe ( Fig. 6A ). These are connected by a loop between α7 and β10. The putative anthocyanin-binding pocket is constructed between these two lobes, the bottom of which is linked to the acyl-CoA binding site. The estimated anthocyanin binding pocket volume was 268 Å 3 , calculated using the POCASA program (
). The surface model of the anthocyanin-binding pocket is shown in Fig. 6A . Since the crystal structure of the anthocyanin• AT complex has yet to be elucidated, we conducted a docking model study to investigate the positional selectivity of anthocyanin 3,5,3 ′ -triglucoside for Gt5,3 ′ AT ( Fig. 6B ). The results revealed that eight of the ten docking poses, including those showing the highest docking score, indicated acyl group transfer at position 5, including the top score. This suggests that Gt5,3 ′ AT preferred acyl group transfer at position 5 to that at position 3’. In the model structures, anthocyanin 3,5,3 ′ -triglucoside binding could be stabilized by van der Waals contacts with hydrophobic amino acids: Trp37, Leu40, Met43, Val232, Phe236, Ile391, Phe396, Ile399, Ala428, and Leu430. These amino acids consist of the side wall of the putative anthocyanin-binding pocket. In addition, each binding mode (at positions 5 and 3 ′ ) had some hydrogen bonds with the hydroxyl groups of glucose. Ser316, Ser393, Ile391, Asn389, and Gly398 were related to hydrogen bonds in the model of transfer at position 5, and Ser316, Ser388, Ile399, Tyr427, and Glu 429 in the model of transfer at position 3’. The results are summarized in Supplementary Figure S2 .

Eg5 AT and Gt5,3 ′ AT are functionally similar and their amino acid sequences are closely related. Eg5 AT transfers the aromatic acyl group to anthocyanin at position 5, whereas Gt5,3 ′ AT transfers it at positions 5 and 3’. The homology model indicated the corresponding amino acids between Gt5,3 ′ AT and Eg5 AT . Although these enzymes shared amino acids within the anthocyanin binding pocket, differences were observed at several positions: (Gt5,3 ′ AT /Eg5 AT , “prime” indicates the residue in These results are consistent with our previous observations (
), as well as the structures of anthocyanins that gentian and lisianthus accumulate. These results led us to analyze the chimeric enzymes of Gt5,3 ′ AT and Eg5 AT in subsequent experiments.

sec.title: 2.4. Analysis of chimeric acyltransferases made of Gt5,3 ′ AT and Eg5 AT
sec.p:
When delphinidin 3,5,3 ′ -triglucoside and caffeoyl-CoA were utilized as substrates, Gt5,3 ′ AT-catalyzed the synthesis of gentiodelphin (delphinidin 3-glucoside 5-caffeoyl-glucoside 3 ′ -caffeoyl-glucoside) and delphinidin 3-glucoside 5-caffeoyl-glucoside 3 ′ -glucoside ( Fig. 7A ). Eg5 AT catalyzed the synthesis of delphinidin 3,3 ′ -diglucoside 5-caffeoyl-glucoside ( Fig. 7D ) and a very small amount of gentiodelphin. Interestingly, Eg5 AT was able to catalyze the acylation of 3 ′ -glucoside. This is an unexpected result since lisianthus does not accumulate gentiodelphin but is in agreement with the structural analysis mentioned above. Under the same conditions, a chimeric AT with Gt5,3 ′ AT at the Nterminal side and Eg5 AT at the C-terminal side (GEAT) and a chimeric AT with Eg5 AT at the N-terminal side and Gt5,3 ′ AT at the C-terminal side (EGAT) resulted in gentiodelphin, in addition to delphinidin 3, 3 ′ - diglucoside 5-caffeoyl-glucoside ( Fig. 7B and C , Fig. 8 ). The order of the ability of these enzymes to synthesize gentiodelphin was as follows: Gt5,3 ′ AT > EGAT > GEAT ≓ Eg5 AT , although the activities of GEAT and Eg5 AT were very low. These results indicate that EGAT has 5,3 ′ AT activity and that the C-terminal side may be crucial for determining the positions of the glucosides of delphinidin 3,5,3 ′ -triglucoside. Most amino acid differences were found in the C-lobe area in the putative anthocyanin binding pocket, as described in the previous section. Gt5,3 ′ AT may have evolved from the preceding 5 AT by acquiring 3 ′ - AT activity with changing amino acid residues. Additionally, ancestral
Gentiana
plants acquired the gene encoding 3 ′ -glucosyltransferase to generate blue gentiodelphin.
Gentiana
plants are mostly alpine in contrast to the related genera (
), and a blue flower color may be beneficial for attracting pollinators, such as bees, to maintain high genetic diversity in alpine regions (
).

Eg5 AT ) Asn41/Tyr41 ′ , Met235/Leu234 ′ , Lys242/Gly241 ′ , Arg245/ Gln244 ′ , Asn389/Lys389 ′ , Pro392/Leu392 ′ , Phe396/Leu396 ′ , Thr400/ Ser400 ′ , and Glu429/Gly429’. The hydrophobic amino acids present in the putative anthocyanin-binding pocket (mentioned above) are conserved between Gt5,3 ′ AT /Eg5 AT , and these amino acids are considered to be important for maintaining the backbone structure of the pocket. However, two differences were observed in the hydrogenbonding amino acids. Asn 389 in Gt5,3 ′ AT is Lys389 ′ in Eg5 AT . These amino acid residues have an amide or amino group, and may be involved in the formation of alternative hydrogen bonds in each structure. Another difference was Glu429/Gly429’. In the Gt5,3 ′ AT docking model, the Glu429 residue forms a hydrogen bond and contributes to anthocyanin binding stability, whereas Gly429 ′ showed no contribution to Eg5 AT . The docking model studies were performed to elucidate the roles of these residues, and the studies supported this observation. The two positions (Asn389 and Glu429) are involved in interaction with the glucose moiety. Subsequently, the anthocyanin 3,5,3 ′ -triglucoside selectivity for these enzymes is 5 > 3 ′ for Gt5,3 ′ AT and 5»3 ′ for Eg5 AT .

sec.title: 3.1. Protein expression and purification for crystallization
Orphanage
sec.p:
Gt5,3 ′ AT was cloned into the expression vector pDEST10.1 (Invitrogen/Thermo Fisher Scientific, Beverly, USA ) as a fusion with an Nterminal His tag and a TEV protease cleavage site. Gt5,3 ′ AT was expressed in Sf9 cells using the Bac-to-Bac Baculovirus Expression System (Invitrogen). The C-terminal truncated mutant Gt5,3 ′ AT (residues 1–465, His174Ala) with an N-terminal SUMO tag was expressed in a cell-free expression system (
).

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Gt5,3 ′ AT and truncated Gt5,3 ′ AT were purified by chromatography using a HisTrap column (GE Healthcare Japan , Tokyo ), and then subjected to TEV protease and SUMO protease digestion, respectively. The proteins were subsequently purified using anion exchange chromatography (HiTrap Q and MonoQ) and Superdex75 (GE Healthcare Japan ) gel filtration chromatography steps. Gt5,3 ′ AT and truncated Gt5,3 ′ AT were concentrated in 20 mM Tris-HCl buffer (pH 8.0) containing 150 mM NaCl and 1 mM TCEP, to a final concentration of 3 and 1. 5 mg /mL, respectively.

sec.title: 3.2. Crystallization and data collection
3.3. Structure determination and refinement
3.4. Ligand docking simulations
3.5. Sequence comparisons and homology modeling of Eustoma acyltransferase
sec.p:
A sequence similarity search was conducted using protein-protein BLAST (https://blast.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/Blast.cgi) against the Protein Data Bank database with the Gt5,3 ′ AT sequence as a query. Sequence alignments were performed using ClustalW (https://www.genome.jp /tools-bin/clustalw). The homology model was built for the
Eustoma
hydroxycinnamoyltransferase (hydroxycinnamoyl-CoA:anthocyanin 5- glucoside-6’’’-O-hydroxycinnamoyltransferase; GenBANK ID: BAF49288.1; Eg5 AT ) using Modellar (
) and the standard protocol. The Gt5,3 ′ AT •caffeoyl-CoA complex structure (this study) was used as the template model. Homology modeling was performed for the Eg5 AT sequence from 6 to 465.

sec.title:
3.6. Characterization of chimeric acyltransferases derived from Gt5, 3 ′ AT
and Eg5 AT
sec.p:
Two chimeric cDNAs with the Gt5,3 ′ AT sequence on the 5 side and Eg5 AT sequence on the 3 ′ side and vice versa were constructed using the Xba I site located in the middle of both sequences (TCTAGA: Ser237- Arg238). These sequences were cloned into the expression vector pET32c (Novagen, Darmstadt, Germany ) and expressed in
Escherichia coli
. The resultant proteins were designated GEAT and EGAT, respectively. In addition, the Gt5,3 ′ AT and Eg5 AT sequences were expressed for comparison. The crude soluble extracts were obtained by sonication of the cells in 10 mM Tris buffer (pH 8.0) containing 1 mM DTT. The extracts were subjected to Bio-Scale Mini Macro-Prep High Q Cartridge (Bio-Rad Laboratories, Hercules, USA ), and the fractions containing anthocyanin AT activities were recovered with 10 mM Tris buffer (pH 8.0) containing 500 mM NaCl and 1 mM DTT. They were subjected to an anthocyanin AT assay since further purification was not possible because of the low quantities of the recombinant enzymes in the soluble fractions. The assay mixture consisted of 127 μМ delphinidin 3,5,3 ′ - triglucoside, 400 μМ caffeoyl CoA, and 50 mM Tris buffer (pH 8.0). The crude extract was kept at 30 ◦ C for 30 min and the reaction was terminated by the addition of the same volume of 90% acetonitrile and 0.1% TFA. The supernatants resulting from centrifugation were subjected to reversed-phase HPLC analysis as described previously (
) to measure areas of delphinidin 3,5,3 ′ -triglucosides, delphinidin 3-glucoside 5-caffeoyl-glucoside 3 ′ -glucoside and gentiodelphin. The relative ratio of delphinidin 3-glucoside 5-caffeoyl-glucoside 3 ′ -glucoside to gentiodelphin was adopted to assess the ability of the enzyme to catalyze acylation of 3 ′ -glucoside.

Acknowledgment

for their assistance during data collection. We would like to thank Editage (www.editage.com) for English language editing.
